image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: Peter Dutton says he was made aware of another allegation against Senator David Van and that the senator should quit parliament, following claims made by Senator Lidia Thorpe and former senator Amanda Stoker in recent days.

title.children: Peter Dutton says Senator David Van should quit parliament, after another allegation raised with him

image.altText: A mug shot of a man

items.synopsis: He's already serving three life sentences after confessing to a trio of underworld murders. Now Abuzar Sultani has been sentenced for his role in the death of a teenager in Sydney 10 years ago.

title.children: Judge describes hit man's rehabilitation as 'pointless exercise' as he jails him for fourth Sydney murder

image.altText: two men close up

items.synopsis: The independent politician, who is suing the NSW One Nation leader for defamation, says his offensive tweet was seen by 6,171 people on Twitter.

title.children: Mark Latham's tweet at centre of defamation storm seen by 6,000 people, court documents allege

image.altText: Kiwi crossing in New Zealand

items.synopsis: New Zealand was among the first developed economies to start increasing interest rates, and it is yet to see inflation in its target zone. This is how the country compares to Australia.

title.children: New Zealand is officially in a recession. These charts show how Australia compares

image.altText: LIz Indrans

items.synopsis: A report by Swinburne University of Technology found 10 companies that trialled a four-day work week continued it after a pilot, with four organisations adopting the change permanently.

title.children: These employers have introduced four-day work weeks and 'can't think of a downside'

image.altText: Ice in the ocean

items.synopsis: This year has already produced record high ocean temperatures, record low Antarctic sea ice, and global air temperatures well above average all year.

title.children: Sudden surge of record high temperatures could propel 2023 as warmest year on record

image.altText: Bunch of flowers with a note a attached.

items.synopsis: A fundraiser to help those affected by the fatal bus crash in the NSW Hunter Valley raises an astonishing amount of money, as hundreds gather for a community vigil at the crash site.

title.children: More than $240k donated to Hunter Valley wedding bus crash victims and their families

image.altText: Man wearing a black top with red stripe, standing outside.

items.synopsis: Amid a shift away from opioids — with prescriptions dropping 30 per cent between 2016 and 2021 — chronic pain sufferers like Daniel King are experiencing acute distress.

title.children: 'It's soul destroying': A shift away from opioid prescriptions is causing distress for people with chronic pain

image.altText: A close-up of Prime Minister Boris Johnson during a televised address.

items.synopsis: Throughout the partygate scandal, Boris Johnson maintained "hand on heart" he believed the lockdown parties were lawful. Here's why a parliamentary committee didn't believe him.

title.children: How Boris Johnson became the first prime minister to deliberately mislead the UK parliament

image.altText: Screenshot from a video showing a police car and people holding up a tarp by the road

items.synopsis: Video from the scene showed firefighters spraying water on a burning white vehicle that was in a ditch to the side of the road.

title.children: At least 15 people dead in Canada as truck hits bus carrying elderly people

image.altText: Man in hat standing at fence with sunset in the background.

items.synopsis: A weather blackout zone in the heart of the country means graziers don't know what the sky will do, and the Bureau of Meteorology can't tell them.

title.children: Weather apps are a farmer's best friend, but in this outback town they're useless

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: AGL's bottom line is set to get a big boost while consumers are hit with rising energy bills. And local shares are trading higher today, after a Wall Street rally. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: AGL to double profits, Wall Street rallies, Europe lifts rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: High energy prices might be hurting consumers, but they're great for AGL. The energy giant expects to double its profit next year. The news has boosted the energy giant's share price in early trade. The ASX 200 is up 0.4 per cent to 7,205.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AGL top of the pack

children.content: High energy prices might be hurting consumers, but they're great for AGL. The energy giant expects to double its profit next year.
The news has boosted the energy giant's share price in early trade.
The ASX 200 is up 0.4 per cent to 7,205.
Gains and Declines at 10:20am
(ASX)
ASX 200 sectors
(ASX)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: AGL has announced its on track to deliver a bumper profit due to higher wholesale electricity prices and improved performance. The energy giant has narrowed its underlying earnings guidance to $1.33bn and $1.38bn. Its previous forecast was between $1.25bn and $1.38bn. Under underlying profit after tax is put at $255m to $285m, and previous guidance was $200m-$280m. Next year it expects to double its underlying profit after tax to $580mn and $780mn. Profit guidance for FY24 EBITDA was between $1.87bn and $2.17bn. AGL gave the following reasons for its profit guidance upgrade: Sustained periods of higher wholesale electricity pricing, reflected in pricing outcomes and reset  through contract positions. Expected improved plant availability and flexibility of the asset fleet, including the commencement of  operations of the Torrens Island and Broken Hill batteries, and the non-recurrence of forced outages  and market volatility impacts from July 2022 of ~$130 million (pre-tax). "Looking ahead to FY24, without the challenging energy market conditions that we saw at the start of this financial year, namely widespread planned and unplanned outages coupled with unprecedented market volatility, we expect FY24 to be a stronger year as we see the sustained recovery of wholesale electricity prices roll through," Chief executive Damien Nicks said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AGL announces massive profit forecast as wholesale electricity prices soar

children.content: AGL has announced its on track to deliver a bumper profit due to higher wholesale electricity prices and improved performance.
The energy giant has narrowed its underlying earnings guidance to $1.33bn and $1.38bn. Its previous forecast was between $1.25bn and $1.38bn.
Under underlying profit after tax is put at $255m to $285m, and previous guidance was $200m-$280m.
Next year it expects to double its underlying profit after tax to $580mn and $780mn.
Profit guidance for FY24 EBITDA was between $1.87bn and $2.17bn.
AGL gave the following reasons for its profit guidance upgrade:
Sustained periods of higher wholesale electricity pricing, reflected in pricing outcomes and reset  through contract positions.

Expected improved plant availability and flexibility of the asset fleet, including the commencement of  operations of the Torrens Island and Broken Hill batteries, and the non-recurrence of forced outages  and market volatility impacts from July 2022 of ~$130 million (pre-tax).

"Looking ahead to FY24, without the challenging energy market conditions that we saw at the start of this financial year, namely widespread planned and unplanned outages coupled with unprecedented market volatility, we expect FY24 to be a stronger year as we see the sustained recovery of wholesale electricity prices roll through," Chief executive Damien Nicks said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US Federal Reserve and the Securities and Exchange Commission are investigating Goldman Sachs Group's role in two deals with Silicon Valley Bank that preceded the latter's collapse, the Wall Street Journal r eported on Thursday citing people familiar with the matter. Silicon Valley Bank had booked a $US1.8 billion loss on the sale of a bond portfolio to Goldman. The Wall Street giant was also an underwriter for a failed share sale by the bank that eventually paved the way for its meltdown. The Fed and the SEC are seeking documents related to Goldman's role as both buyer of the securities portfolio and adviser on the capital raise, the report said. They are looking to see if Goldman's investment banking side and its trading division were improperly communicating about the portfolio sale, the report added. Goldman had d isclosed last month it was cooperating with government probes into its dealings with Silicon Valley Bank. "SVB engaged Goldman Sachs to assist with a proposed capital raise and sold the firm a portfolio of securities. Prior to that sale, Goldman Sachs informed SVB in writing that we would not act as their advisor on the sale, and that SVB should not rely on any advice from the bank in this regard, but instead hire a third-party financial advisor," a spokesperson for Goldman said. Goldman's shares closed up 0.4% at $US339.12, after having risen as much as 1.6% earlier in the day. In March, Reuters reported US prosecutors were investigating the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. The probe by the Fed and the SEC were part of the broader probes, the WSJ report added. An SEC spokesperson said in an emailed statement the agency "does not comment on the existence or nonexistence of a possible investigation". A spokesperson for the Fed declined to comment. Silicon Valley Bank's demise sent shockwaves through the industry and brought on the worst crisis for the sector in 15 years. - Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fed, SEC probing Goldman Sachs' role in Silicon Valley Bank's final days

children.content: The US Federal Reserve and the Securities and Exchange Commission are investigating Goldman Sachs Group's role in two deals with Silicon Valley Bank that preceded the latter's collapse, the Wall Street Journal
r
eported
on Thursday citing people familiar with the matter.

Silicon Valley Bank had booked a $US1.8 billion loss on the sale of a bond portfolio to Goldman. The Wall Street giant was also an underwriter for a failed share sale by the bank that eventually paved the way for its meltdown.
The Fed and the SEC are seeking documents related to Goldman's role as both buyer of the securities portfolio and adviser on the capital raise, the report said.
They are looking to see if Goldman's investment banking side and its trading division were improperly communicating about the portfolio sale, the report added.
Goldman had
d
isclosed last month it was cooperating with government probes into its dealings with Silicon Valley Bank.

"SVB engaged Goldman Sachs to assist with a proposed capital raise and sold the firm a portfolio of securities. Prior to that sale, Goldman Sachs informed SVB in writing that we would not act as their advisor on the sale, and that SVB should not rely on any advice from the bank in this regard, but instead hire a third-party financial advisor," a spokesperson for Goldman said.
Goldman's shares closed up 0.4% at $US339.12, after having risen as much as 1.6% earlier in the day.
In March, Reuters reported
US prosecutors were investigating the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. The probe by the Fed and the SEC were part of the broader probes, the WSJ report added.
An SEC spokesperson said in an emailed statement the agency "does not comment on the existence or nonexistence of a possible investigation". A spokesperson for the Fed declined to comment.
Silicon Valley Bank's demise sent shockwaves through the industry and brought on the worst crisis for the sector in 15 years.
- Reuters

image.altText: Joko Widodo sitting in front of a microphone

items.synopsis: Treasury staff must register all gifts received. Those over $100 go on the internet. Those below that value have been uncovered in FOI documents obtained by the ABC.

title.children: Treasury gets the chocolates as gift registry exposed

image.altText: Chief Justice Susan Kiefel.

items.synopsis: The first woman to be the chief justice of the High Court, Susan Kiefel announces her early retirement from the highest court in the land.

title.children: Trailblazing justice Susan Kiefel to retire early from the High Court

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it is pushing Russian forces back in places along the southern and eastern frontlines, while Moscow announces plans for elections in occupied areas in its latest bid to signal it is in control.

title.children: Bodycam vision shows intense gunfights as Ukraine pushes on with counteroffensive

image.altText: A teenager in a beanie looking at a phone

items.synopsis: The latest crime statistics show teenage burglaries in Victoria have increased by a staggering 86 per cent.

title.children: Thieves as young as 10 behind dramatic rise in home burglaries, car theft

image.altText: Crab pots in a skip bin and laid out next to a shed.

items.synopsis: A total of 195 "ghost" pots have been pulled from a south-east Queensland waterway, in a three-day clean-up operation by marine park rangers and fisheries officers.

title.children: Fishers 'gobsmacked' by record-breaking haul of illegal crab pots

image.altText: A woman looks to the sky as she holds the end wall of a swimming pool.

items.synopsis: Mollie O'Callaghan's meteoric rise in Australian swimming continues, as Queenslanders dominate the pool in Melbourne.

title.children: O'Callaghan 'over the moon' after pipping Titmus, as Queenslanders dominate Aussie swimming trials

image.altText: Lachie Dent and Chantelle Bongers smiling in a selfie taken at a bar next to bright blue water.

items.synopsis: Amid rising inflation and interest rates and stubbornly high prices for flights, the number of Australian residents travelling overseas has yet to return to pre-pandemic levels. But some countries are getting more Australian visitors than others.

title.children: Fiji wasn't Lachie and Chantelle's first choice of holiday destination. But the cheaper option turned out to be the best

image.altText: A group of women run around a track.

items.synopsis: Aussie runners push their global rivals at the Bislett Games, and claim Australian records with strong performances in Oslo.

title.children: Jess Hull and Olli Hoare power to Australian records at the Bislett Games in Oslo

image.altText: a photo of a phone that shows 'SOS"

items.synopsis: Claire Harrison says she's still recovering from losing her identity and tens of thousands of dollars by mobile porting fraud, where scammers port your mobile number to another device.

title.children: 'Terrifying' phone porting scam stealing millions but cybersecurity experts say it's unavoidable

image.altText: Picture of a sign saying caution with an open pit coal mine and power station in the background

items.synopsis: A supposed exemplar of energy security and prescience just last year, Western Australia is now facing calls for a shake-up of its policies amid soaring prices and supply strains.

title.children: Australia's energy woes shift west as state's power and gas prices head skywards

image.altText: An aerial photo shows an overcrowded boat on a blue sea.

items.synopsis: As authorities continue to look for the hundreds of missing passengers, nine survivors accused of being part of the smuggling ring behind the tragedy are arrested.

title.children: Coast guard arrests nine survivors from capsized migrant ship as fears grow of hundreds drowned in seas off Greece

image.altText: Close-up of rifle trigger.

items.synopsis: A gunman charged with shooting at a car with two people and their infant inside allegedly told the driver of the vehicle, the next time "I won't f***ing miss you".

title.children: Canberra man who allegedy used a rifle to shoot at car with baby inside told driver he 'wouldn't miss' next time

image.altText: Argentina's Lionel Messi shoots the ball at the goal.

items.synopsis: The irrepressible Lionel Messi again brings the Socceroos' undone, scoring the fastest goal of his international career as Argentina claims a friendly victory in Beijing.

title.children: Messi makes history again as Argentina defeats Socceroos

image.altText: White house with grey flat roof and a concrete driveway, looks over suburbs from cul de sac

items.synopsis: In one Hobart street, 22 new homes have been deemed uninhabitable. Now the local council has ordered three of them be demolished.

title.children: Owners ordered to demolish 'unsafe' Hobart homes

image.altText: Three Aboriginal kids in school uniforms stand in front of a science display

items.synopsis: Students from the remote Northern Territory homeland of Nganambala are using space-inspired technology to design infrastructure for their community.

title.children: In this remote community, there is no phone reception. These kids are working to change that

image.altText: A prison mugshot of Duane Owen in an orange jumpsuit

items.synopsis: One of Florida's longest-held death row inmates, Owen was 23 at the time of the attacks and 62 when he was executed.

title.children: US man executed over 1984 killings of teenage babysitter and mother-of-two

image.altText: A man smiles.

items.synopsis: The yachtsman, winemaker and businessman — who was part of the team that wrested the America's Cup from the United States — dies in Adelaide aged 90.

title.children: Champion yachtsman and wine boss Sir James Hardy dies aged 90

image.altText: A woman hits a cricket ball.

items.synopsis: Australia's search for a new Test opening pairing appears to end as Beth Mooney dominates the England A attack in Leicester.

title.children: Ashes opening pairing firms for Australia as Beth Mooney dominates in warm up clash

image.altText: An image of a person abseiling, next to a man wearing a helmet.

items.synopsis: For years, Aardvark Adventures has sent abseilers over the edge of a spectacularly high dam in Tasmania's south-west. But the business has been asked to undergo safety testing before it can renew its licence, and its owner-operator wants the state government to help pay for it.

title.children: Future of abseiling business hanging in the air over safety-testing requirements

image.altText: A court sketch illustration shows a middle-aged white male judge questioning a young white man with short hair.

items.synopsis: The 21-year-old is accused of committing one of the most serious US security breaches since more than 700,000 files appeared on WikiLeaks.

title.children: Man accused of leaking US military secrets on Discord indicted by grand jury

image.altText: A woman in a white shirt with short brown hair in a still from a movie

items.synopsis: Dial of Destiny is the fifth and final instalment in the Indiana Jones franchise, which started with 1981’s Raiders of the Lost Ark.

title.children: 'He's as mad as a box of squirrels': Behind the scenes of the final Indiana Jones adventure

image.altText: Four swimmers diving into a pool ahead of a race.

items.synopsis: The Australian Sports Commission releases its guidelines for the inclusion of transgender and gender diverse athletes in high-performance sport.

title.children: High-performance guidelines released for transgender and gender diverse inclusion in Australian sport
